coredata.dc:title: Mining data from hemodynamic simulations for generating prediction and explanation models
coredata.prism:publicationName: IEEE Transactions on Information Technology in Biomedicine

abstract.ce:para: One of the most common causes of human death is stroke, which can be caused by carotid bifurcation stenosis. In our work, we aim at proposing a prototype of a medical expert system that could significantly aid medical experts to detect hemodynamic abnormalities (increased artery wall shear stress). Based on the acquired simulated data, we apply several methodologies for1) predicting magnitudes and locations of maximum wall shear stress in the artery, 2) estimating reliability of computed predictions, and 3) providing user-friendly explanation of the models decision. The obtained results indicate that the evaluated methodologies can provide a useful tool for the given problem domain. © 2012 IEEE.

affiliation.affilname: Research and Development Center for Bioengineering BioIRC

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Manuscript received April 15, 2011; revised July 5, 2011; accepted July 26, 2011. Date of publication August 15, 2011; date of current version March 7, 2012. This work was supported by European Commission (Project ARTREAT, ICT 224297) and Bilateral project Serbia-Slovenia 2010–2011. Z. Bosnić, P. Vracˇar, and I. Kononenko are with the University of Ljubljana, Faculty of Computer and Information Science (e-mail: zoran.bosnic@ fri.uni-lj.si; petar.vracar@fri.uni-lj.si; igor.kononenko@fri.uni-lj.si). M. D. Radović is with the Research and Development Center for Bioengineering “BioIRC,” Kragujevac, Serbia (e-mail: mradovic@kg.ac.rs). G. Devedzˇić and N. D. Filipović are with the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Kragujevac, Serbia (e-mail: fica@kg.ac.rs; devedzic@kg.ac.rs). Color versions of one or more of the figures in this paper are available online at http://ieeexplore.ieee.org. Digital Object Identifier 10.1109/TITB.2011.2164546

item-info.copyright: Copyright 2012 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

abstract.ce:para: One of the most common causes of human death is stroke, which can be caused by carotid bifurcation stenosis. In our work, we aim at proposing a prototype of a medical expert system that could significantly aid medical experts to detect hemodynamic abnormalities (increased artery wall shear stress). Based on the acquired simulated data, we apply several methodologies for1) predicting magnitudes and locations of maximum wall shear stress in the artery, 2) estimating reliability of computed predictions, and 3) providing user-friendly explanation of the models decision. The obtained results indicate that the evaluated methodologies can provide a useful tool for the given problem domain. © 2012 IEEE.
